messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: The Element Extraction Problem and the Cost of Determinism and Limited Adaptivity in Linear Queries

Paper Abstract: Abstract Two widely-used computational paradigms for sublinear algorithms are using linear measurements to perform computations on a high dimensional input and using structured queries to access a massive input. Typically, algorithms in the former paradigm are non-adaptive whereas those in the latter are highly adaptive. This work studies the fundamental search problem of element-extraction in a query model that combines both: linear measurements with bounded adaptivity. In the element-extraction problem, one is given a nonzero vector ùê≥=(z1,‚Ä¶,zn)‚àà{0,1}nùê≥subscriptùëß1‚Ä¶subscriptùëßùëõsuperscript01ùëõ\mathbf{z}=(z_{1},\ldots,z_{n})\in\{0,1\}^{n} and must report an index iùëñi where zi=1subscriptùëßùëñ1z_{i}=1. The input can be accessed using arbitrary linear functions of it with coefficients in some ring. This problem admits an efficient nonadaptive randomized solution (through the well known technique of ‚Ñì0subscript‚Ñì0\ell_{0}-sampling) and an efficient fully adaptive deterministic solution (through binary search). We prove that when confined to only kùëòk rounds of adaptivity, a deterministic element-extraction algorithm must spend Œ©‚Äã(k‚Äã(n1/k‚àí1))Œ©ùëòsuperscriptùëõ1ùëò1\Omega(k(n^{1/k}-1)) queries, when working in the ring of integers modulo some fixed qùëûq. This matches the corresponding upper bound. For queries using integer arithmetic, we prove a 222-round Œ©~‚Äã(n)~Œ©ùëõ\widetilde{\Omega}(\sqrt{n}) lower bound, also tight up to polylogarithmic factors. Our proofs reduce to classic problems in combinatorics, and take advantage of established results on the zero-sum problem as well as recent improvements to the sunflower lemma. Keywords: query complexity; linear measurements; sketching; round elimination Acknowledgements: We thank Deeparnab Chakrabarty, Prantar Ghosh, and anonymous reviewers for several helpful discussions, comments, and pointers. This work was supported in part by NSF under award 2006589.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Learning with limited rounds of adaptivity: Coin tossing, multi-armed bandits, and ranking from pairwise comparisons",
        "On learning graphs with edge-detecting queries",
        "Separations in query complexity based on pointer functions",
        "Graph connectivity and single element recovery via linear and or queries",
        "Analyzing graph structure via linear measurements",
        "Improved bounds for the sunflower lemma",
        "Note on sunflowers",
        "Complexity measures and decision tree complexity: a survey",
        "Edge estimation with independent set oracles",
        "Communication steps for parallel query processing",
        "The adaptive complexity of maximizing a submodular function",
        "Optimal algorithms for the coin weighing problem with a spring scale",
        "Robust lower bounds for communication and stream computation",
        "A unifying framework for ‚Ñì‚Ñì\\ell0-sampling algorithms",
        "An adaptivity hierarchy theorem for property testing",
        "Strong fooling sets for multi-player communication with applications to deterministic estimation of stream statistics",
        "An optimal randomised cell probe lower bound for approximate nearest neighbour searching",
        "Incidence geometries and the pass complexity of semi-streaming set cover",
        "Small Summaries for Big Data",
        "A lower bound of the ¬Ωn2 on linear search programs for the knapsack problem",
        "Compressed sensing",
        "Intersection theorems for systems of sets",
        "On two problems of information theory",
        "Semi-streaming set cover",
        "Sampling in dynamic data streams and applications",
        "Intersection theorems with geometric consequences",
        "Zero-sum problems in finite abelian groups: A survey",
        "Stream order and order statistics: Quantile estimation in random-order streams",
        "Superlinear lower bounds for multipass graph processing",
        "Almost optimal lower bounds for small depth circuits",
        "Structure of protocols for XOR functions",
        "Optimality of linear sketching under modular updates",
        "Tight bounds for lpsubscriptùëôùëùl_{p} samplers, finding duplicates in streams, and related problems",
        "Near-optimal linear decision trees for k-sum and related problems",
        "Linear sketching over f_2",
        "Optimal lower bounds for universal relation, and for samplers and finding duplicates in streams",
        "An optimal algorithm for the distinct elements problem",
        "Adaptive sparse recovery with limited adaptivity",
        "The complexity of parallel search",
        "Monotone circuits for connectivity require super-logarithmic depth",
        "Search problems in the decision tree model",
        "Turnstile streaming algorithms might as well be linear sketches",
        "Randomized approximate nearest neighbor search with limited adaptivity",
        "Searching for a subset of counterfeit coins: Randomization vs determinism and adaptiveness vs non-adaptiveness",
        "On data structures and asymmetric communication complexity",
        "Data streams: Algorithms and applications",
        "The demand query model for bipartite matching",
        "Rounds in communication complexity revisited",
        "Optimal lower bounds for distributed and streaming spanning forest computation",
        "A combinatorial problem on finite abelian groups, i",
        "Randomization does not help searching predecessors",
        "Lower bounds for adaptive sparse recovery",
        "Coding for sunflowers",
        "The average sensitivity of bounded-depth formulas",
        "Lower bounds for predecessor searching in the cell probe model",
        "The sunflower lemma via Shannon entropy",
        "The communication complexity of the universal relation",
        "A combinatorial problem on finite abelian groups III",
        "Sketching as a tool for numerical linear algebra",
        "On the parity complexity measures of boolean functions"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in The Element Extraction Problem and the Cost of Determinism and Limited Adaptivity in Linear Queries, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
